QuestionLookupSet.description: Are your needs due to a physical or mental impairment or illness?
Does eligibility for NHS continuing care require consideration? (if so use checklist)
Do you manage your own finances? (detail arrangements, including any difficulties)
Do you have any financial difficulties? (e.g. paying bills, living within your means)
Do you have difficulty applying for or receiving benefits?

Has your home been adapted to meet your needs?

Are you able to maintain a comfortable temperature in your home?
Other mental health issues? (e.g. delusions, hallucinations, severe mental illness)
Have you had contact with mental health services in the past year?
Are you able to respond to emergencies?

Do you have concerns about how others treat you? (e.g. neglect, abuse, discrimination)
Loss of support from your carer
Harm or injury to your carer

Are there any areas where a positive approach to risk may be beneficial?
Do you have any personal preferences regarding your support or care? (e.g. gender)
Do you have concerns about the quality of support you currently receive?
Are you happy to accept personal care provided by a formal/paid carer?

Text.Content: Using the following scale
0= Does not need support in this activity, e.g. does this independently, chooses not to do it or is unable to do it e.g. ill health, retired.
1= Needs occasional support, e.g. on a bad day, at most once a week.
2= Needs regular support, 2-3 times a week.
3= Needs daily support, on about one occasion per day.
4= Needs intensive daily support, on more than one occasion per day or for an extended period each day.

Fieldset.legend: Employment Status

RepeatingTable.title: How does the caring role impact on the carer’s well being?

Help.Content: Please consider preventative and community options.

Content.ns6:Para: Repeat for each significant carer
Consider your ability to wash yourself and launder your clothes for example

TableColumn.title: How the person wants the outcome to be achieved

Content.ns6:Para: Where a person has fluctuating needs the needs must be considered over a sufficient period of time to get a complete picture of those needs.

When completing identified level of need, please do not consider needs that are currently being met by an unpaid carer who is willing and able to continue providing support. This does not affect the person’s eligibility decision.
Consider your ability to dress yourself and to be appropriately dressed, for instance in relation to the weather to maintain your health.

TableColumn.title: How the person wants the outcome to be achieved

Content.ns6:Para: Where a person has fluctuating needs the needs must be considered over a sufficient period of time to get a complete picture of those needs.

When completing identified level of need, please do not consider needs that are currently being met by an unpaid carer who is willing and able to continue providing support. This does not affect the person’s eligibility decision.
Consider your ability to access and use a toilet and manage your toilet needs.

TableColumn.title: How the person wants the outcome to be achieved

Content.ns6:Para: Where a person has fluctuating needs the needs must be considered over a sufficient period of time to get a complete picture of those needs.

When completing identified level of need, please do not consider needs that are currently being met by an unpaid carer who is willing and able to continue providing support. This does not affect the person’s eligibility decision.

Subsection.title: Being able to make use of the home safely

Content.ns6:Para: Consider your ability to move around your home safely, which could for example include getting up steps or accessing the rooms. This should also include the immediate environment around your home such as access to the property, for example steps leading up to your home.

TableColumn.title: How the person wants the outcome to be achieved

Content.ns6:Para: Where a person has fluctuating needs the needs must be considered over a sufficient period of time to get a complete picture of those needs.

When completing identified level of need, please do not consider needs that are currently being met by an unpaid carer who is willing and able to continue providing support. This does not affect the person’s eligibility decision.
Consider whether you have access to food and drink to maintain nutrition, and if you are able to prepare and consume the food and drink.

TableColumn.title: How the person wants the outcome to be achieved

Content.ns6:Para: Where a person has fluctuating needs the needs must be considered over a sufficient period of time to get a complete picture of those needs.

When completing identified level of need, please do not consider needs that are currently being met by an unpaid carer who is willing and able to continue providing support. This does not affect the person’s eligibility decision.

Consider whether the condition of your home home is sufficiently clean and maintained to be safe. You may require support to sustain your occupancy of your home and to maintain amenities, such as water, electricity and gas.

TableColumn.title: How the person wants the outcome to be achieved

Content.ns6:Para: Where a person has fluctuating needs the needs must be considered over a sufficient period of time to get a complete picture of those needs.

When completing identified level of need, please do not consider needs that are currently being met by an unpaid carer who is willing and able to continue providing support. This does not affect the person’s eligibility decision.

Subsection.title: Making use of necessary facilities in the local community

Content.ns6:Para: Consider your ability to get around in the community safely and your ability to use such facilities as public transport, shops or recreational facilities when considering the impact on your well-being

TableColumn.title: How the person wants the outcome to be achieved

Content.ns6:Para: Where a person has fluctuating needs the needs must be considered over a sufficient period of time to get a complete picture of those needs.

When completing identified level of need, please do not consider needs that are currently being met by an unpaid carer who is willing and able to continue providing support. This does not affect the person’s eligibility decision.

Subsection.title: Developing and maintaining family or other personal relationships

Content.ns6:Para: Consider whether you are lonely or isolated, either because your needs prevent you from maintaining the personal relationships you have or because your needs prevent you from developing new relationships.

TableColumn.title: How the person wants the outcome to be achieved

Content.ns6:Para: Where a person has fluctuating needs the needs must be considered over a sufficient period of time to get a complete picture of those needs.

When completing identified level of need, please do not consider needs that are currently being met by an unpaid carer who is willing and able to continue providing support. This does not affect the person’s eligibility decision.

Subsection.title: Accessing and engaging in work, training, education or volunteering

Content.ns6:Para: Consider whether you have an opportunity to apply yourself and contribute to society through work, training, education or volunteering, including the physical access to any facility and support whilst there.

TableColumn.title: How the person wants the outcome to be achieved

Content.ns6:Para: Where a person has fluctuating needs the needs must be considered over a sufficient period of time to get a complete picture of those needs.

When completing identified level of need, please do not consider needs that are currently being met by an unpaid carer who is willing and able to continue providing support. This does not affect the person’s eligibility decision.

Subsection.title: Carrying out any caring responsibilities the adult has for a child

Content.ns6:Para: Consider any parenting or other caring responsibilities you have. You may for example be a step-parent with caring responsibilities for your spouse’s children

TableColumn.title: How the person wants the outcome to be achieved

Content.ns6:Para: Where a person has fluctuating needs the needs must be considered over a sufficient period of time to get a complete picture of those needs.

When completing identified level of need, please do not consider needs that are currently being met by an unpaid carer who is willing and able to continue providing support. This does not affect the person’s eligibility decision.

Text.Content: In considering whether a person's needs are eligible for care and support, local authorities must consider whether:

(a) The adult's needs are due to a physical or mental impairment or illness. This includes conditions such as physical, mental, sensory, learning or cognitive disabilities or illnesses and brain injuries.
(b) The effect of the adult's needs is that the adult is unable to achieve two or more of the outcomes set out in regulations.

(c) Local authorities must consider whether the adult’s needs and their inability to achieve the outcomes cause or risk causing a significant impact on their wellbeing. The meaning of “wellbeing” is set out in Section 1 of the Care Act. Local authorities must determine how the adult’s inability to achieve the outcomes above impacts on their wellbeing. Where the adult is unable to achieve more than one of the outcomes, the local authority does not need to consider the impact of each individually, but should consider whether the cumulative effect of being unable to achieve those outcomes is one of a “significant impact on wellbeing”. In doing so, local authorities should also consider whether:

ns7:BulletList.ns7:BulletPoint: the adult’s inability to achieve the outcomes above impacts on at least one of the areas of wellbeing in a significant way; or,
the effect of the impact on a number of the areas of wellbeing mean that there is a significant impact on the adult's overall wellbeing.

Text.Content: An adult's needs are only eligible where they meet all three of these conditions. In considering the type of needs an adult may have, the local authority should note that there is no hierarchy of needs or of the constituent parts of wellbeing.
Where the adult does not have eligible needs include explanation for this decision

Subsection.title: Estimated budget based on your needs assessment

Text.Content: If appropriate refer for benefits maximisation/financial assessment

Subsection.title: Your Home And Living Situation (current home, rather than where you may be temporarily residing, e.g. in hospital)
Behaviour Affecting Self Or Others (e.g. aggression, self-harm)

best interest.

Content.ns6:Para: Where a person has fluctuating needs the needs must be considered over a sufficient period of time to get a complete picture of those needs.

When completing identified level of need, please do not consider needs that are currently being met by an unpaid carer who is willing and able to continue providing support. This does not affect the person’s eligibility decision.

Text.Content: In considering whether a person's needs are eligible for care and support, local authorities must consider whether:

(a) The adult's needs are due to a physical or mental impairment or illness. This includes conditions such as physical, mental, sensory, learning or cognitive disabilities or illnesses and brain injuries.
(b) The effect of the adult's needs is that the adult is unable to achieve two or more of the outcomes set out in regulations.

(c) Local authorities must consider whether the adult’s needs and their inability to achieve the outcomes cause or risk causing a significant impact on their wellbeing. The meaning of “wellbeing” is set out in Section 1 of the Care Act. Local authorities must determine how the adult’s inability to achieve the outcomes above impacts on their wellbeing. Where the adult is unable to achieve more than one of the outcomes, the local authority does not need to consider the impact of each individually, but should consider whether the cumulative effect of being unable to achieve those outcomes is one of a “significant impact on wellbeing”. In doing so, local authorities should also consider whether:

ns7:BulletList.ns7:BulletPoint: the adult’s inability to achieve the outcomes above impacts on at least one of the areas of wellbeing in a significant way; or,
the effect of the impact on a number of the areas of wellbeing mean that there is a significant impact on the adult's overall wellbeing.

Text.Content: An adult's needs are only eligible where they meet all three of these conditions. In considering the type of needs an adult may have, the local authority should note that there is no hierarchy of needs or of the constituent parts of wellbeing.

Fieldset.legend: Are your needs due to a physical or mental impairment or illness?

Text.Content: Where the adult does not have eligible needs include explanation for this decision

Fieldset.legend: Does eligibility for NHS continuing care require consideration? (if so use checklist)

Subsection.title: Estimated budget based on your needs assessment

Fieldset.legend: Do you manage your own finances? (detail arrangements, including any difficulties)
Do you have any financial difficulties? (e.g. paying bills, living within your means)
Do you have difficulty applying for or receiving benefits?
Receives Attendance Allowance
Receives Disability Living Allowance

Text.Content: If appropriate refer for benefits maximisation/financial assessment

Subsection.title: Your Home And Living Situation (current home, rather than where you may be temporarily residing, e.g. in hospital)

Fieldset.legend: Is your housing situation satisfactory? (homelessness, security of tenure, support provided)
Is your home a suitable and safe environment? (e.g. access, hazards, adaptability)
Has your home been adapted to meet your needs?
Are you currently using telecare?
Do you have a working smoke alarm?
Are you able to maintain a comfortable temperature in your home?

Subsection.title: Behaviour Affecting Self Or Others (e.g. aggression, self-harm)

Fieldset.legend: Other mental health issues? (e.g. delusions, hallucinations, severe mental illness)
Have you had contact with mental health services in the past year?
Are you able to respond to emergencies?
Do you have concerns about how others treat you? (e.g. neglect, abuse, discrimination)

Text.Content: If yes to last question or other indicator of vulnerability follow local Safeguarding Adults guidelines

Medicine mismanagement

The support you need to ensure that you or those around you are safe
Are there any areas where a positive approach to risk may be beneficial?
Do you have any personal preferences regarding your support or care? (e.g. gender)
Do you have concerns about the quality of support you currently receive?
Are you happy to accept personal care provided by a formal/paid carer?
Have you made any advance statements or decisions about care or treatment?

RepeatingTable.title: Details of all parties involved in completing this assessment

Text.Content: *A legal representative is someone who: • Has LPA (Personal Welfare for the purpose of this document) • Holds a Personal Welfare deputyship • Has been specifically authorised by order of the Court of Protection
Or: If the person does not have a legal representative: This document has been agreed by all parties ** as in
best interest.
** Name the parties in the Field below
